values.description:
This PR adds several scripts for controlling the arms, neck and head, using the respective IHMC ROS messages and topic interfaces. Trajectories are named and stored in a yaml file, and each `*_traj_yaml.py` reads from this type of file for the named trajectory.

Here are some examples if your current working directory is the `scripts` sub-folder (I hesitate to install these scripts since the yaml files need to be passed as an argument, and they're just meant to be examples):

~~~
# reset all joints to zero value
python arm_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml arms0
python head_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml head0
python neck_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml neck0
~~~

~~~
# actuate individual joints through their range of motion
python arm_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml arms1
python arm_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml arms2
python arm_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml arms3
python arm_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml arms4
python arm_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml arms5
python arm_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml arms6
python arm_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml arms7
python neck_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml neck1
python neck_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml neck2
python neck_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml neck3
python head_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml headPitch
python head_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml headYaw
~~~

This code currently works to control arms1-4, but in order to control arms5-7 and the neck/head, you will need extra code that hasn't yet been released by IHMC and JSC.

* https://github.com/ihmcrobotics/ihmc-open-robotics-software/tree/hotfix/srcsim-position-control-joints
* https://gitlab.com/nasa-jsc-robotics/val_description/commits/develop

I'll update this PR when the upstream code has been released.
values.title: Example scripts for controlling arms, neck and head

Here are some examples if your current working directory is the scripts sub-folder (I hesitate to install these scripts since the yaml files need to be passed as an argument, and they're just meant to be examples):

# reset all joints to zero value

python head_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml head0
python neck_traj_yaml.py Traj_data.yaml neck0

values.description:
* Hand-picked masses and inertias

![satellite.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2674257339-satellite.png)

* Simple shapes (sphere and cylinder) for collisions around the wheel handles to improve contact

![sat_handle.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3905001825-sat_handle.png)

* Joint friction (resistance effort) calculated to resist approximately 5 pounds of effort considering that the wheel has about 0.1 m radius:


```
5 pounds ~= 2.5 kg
2.5 kg * 9.8 m/s^2 ~= 25 N
25 N * 0.1 m = 2.5 Nm
```

values.description:
First pass of the unique world generating script (`unique.world.erb`).

Also included two example worlds generated with the script:

`unique.world`

![unique_noheightmap.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1963902430-unique_noheightmap.png)

`unique_task1.world`

![task1_noheightmap.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/150314851-task1_noheightmap.png)

### Usage

Generate a world with all 3 tasks:

    erb unique.world.erb > unique.world

Generate a world with only task 1:

    erb t=1 unique.world.erb > unique_task1.world

More models for tasks 2 and 3, launch files and plugins to come.

I'm also working on detailed wiki instructions.

values.description:
Hopefully the documentation on the plugin's header is informative enough. This plugin will be used to verify several of the checkpoints during the finals.

It needs [this](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/146/orientedbox-see-issue-59/diff) ignition math pull request.

I've also added two dependencies:

* ignition-msgs0 (I'm using ignition-msgs_0.6.0, because that uses ign-math2) 

* ignition-transport3 (It looks like the srcsim debs aren't installing any version, so I went ahead and used the latest one)

If adding these dependencies will be too troublesome, I can change the implementation. I did it this way because I thought of porting the plugin to Gazebo 8 soon.

values.description:
Satellite plugin for task 1.

* Transfers wheel rotation to dish rotation

* Publishes satellite status messages on ROS topic `/task1/checkpoint2/satellite`:

```
---
target_pitch: -0.2
target_yaw: 1.0
current_pitch: -0.0306981597753
current_yaw: 0.238853778623
pitch_correct_now: False
yaw_correct_now: False
pitch_completed: False
yaw_completed: False
---
```

* Plugin parameters that will be randomized by the unique world generator:

    - yaw / pitch ratio
    - yaw / pitch PID gains (used from the wheels to the dish)
    - yaw / pitch target angles

* Plugin parameters that can be customized during development:

    - tolerance within which angle is considered correct
    - minimum time which angles must be correct for the checkpoint to be considered complete
    - topic where satellite messages are published
    - frequency with which messages are published

* Also added an almost duplicate of `unique_task1.world` from pull request #26 for testing

* Also added launch file `unique_task1.launch`

* Little tweaks to the plugin are coming, namely a service to toggle it on and off so it is only on while task 1, checkpoint 2 is being checked.

#### Try it out

1. `roslaunch srcsim unique_task1.launch`

2. `rostopic echo /task1/checkpoint2/satellite`

3. Use the Apply Force/Torque tool to rotate the wheels and see how the values change.

values.description:
This plugin will be used to verify several of the checkpoints during the finals.

It needs [this](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/146/orientedbox-see-issue-59/diff) ignition math pull request.

* Competitors should not interact directly with this plugin. A Gazebo transport interface was chosen over ROS in an effort to keep the internal interface well separated from the user-facing one.

* The plugin publishes messages to Gazebo topic `<namespace>/box/contains` with 0 or 1, depending on whether the robot is currently within the given box or not.

```
data: 0
```

* The plugin can be toggled on or off through topic `<namespace>/box/toggle`. Another plugin will be doing the toggling during the competition. For now, feel free to use [this](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/chapulina/kBa86) publisher program for testing.

* Plugin parameters:

    - frequency: Publish frequency in Hz
    - entity: Scoped entity name, using "valkyrie" to check the model origin
    - namespace: Namespace for topics, there will be several of these plugins in the world, for now I'm using namespaces such as `taskN/checkpointN`
    - pose: Box pose in the world frame
    - size: Box size

* Also added an almost duplicate of `unique_task1.world` (with the added plugin) from pull request #26 for testing

* Also added launch file `unique_task1.launch`

### Try it out

1. `roslaunch srcsim unique_task1.launch init:=true`

1. Wait for Val to be lowered by the harness

1. Use the example publisher to toggle the box on: `./publisher`

1. `gz topic -e /task1/checkpoint3/box/contains` to see the 0/1 messages

1. With the translate tool, drag Val into and out of the finish box and observe the publish messages change.

* The plugin can be toggled on or off through topic `<namespace>/box/toggle`. Another plugin will be doing the toggling during the competition. For now, feel free to use [this](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/chapulina/kBa86) publisher program for testing.

* Plugin parameters:

    - frequency: Publish frequency in Hz
    - entity: Scoped entity name, using "valkyrie" to check the model origin
    - namespace: Namespace for topics, there will be several of these plugins in the world, for now I'm using namespaces such as `taskN/checkpointN`
    - pose: Box pose in the world frame
    - size: Box size

* Also added an almost duplicate of `unique_task1.world` (with the added plugin) from pull request #26 for testing

* Also added launch file `unique_task1.launch`

### Try it out

1. `roslaunch srcsim unique_task1.launch init:=true`

1. Wait for Val to be lowered by the harness

1. Use the example publisher to toggle the box on: `./publisher`

1. `gz topic -e /task1/checkpoint3/box/contains` to see the 0/1 messages

1. With the translate tool, drag Val into and out of the finish box and observe the publish messages change.
summary.html:
This plugin will be used to verify several of the checkpoints during the finals.

It needs this ignition math pull request.

  • Competitors should not interact directly with this plugin. A Gazebo transport interface was chosen over ROS in an effort to keep the internal interface well separated from the user-facing one.

  • The plugin publishes messages to Gazebo topic <namespace>/box/contains with 0 or 1, depending on whether the robot is currently within the given box or not.

data: 0

  • The plugin can be toggled on or off through topic <namespace>/box/toggle. Another plugin will be doing the toggling during the competition. For now, feel free to use this publisher program for testing.

    • frequency: Publish frequency in Hz
    • entity: Scoped entity name, using "valkyrie" to check the model origin
    • namespace: Namespace for topics, there will be several of these plugins in the world, for now I'm using namespaces such as taskN/checkpointN
    • pose: Box pose in the world frame

values.description:
This is the skeleton of the plugin which will coordinate each run. A run consists of 3 tasks, each task having from 3 to 8 checkpoints. Each task has a timeout within which all of its checkpoints must be completed.

### Example usage

* Start example world:

    `roslaunch srcsim unique.launch init:=true`

* Wait for initialization to finish (see message `INIT: Done`)

* Start Task 1, Checkpoint 1:

    `rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 1 1`

    You should see these messages:

        [Msg] Task [1] - Checkpoint [1] - Started (26 804000000)
        [Msg] Started box contains plugin [task1/checkpoint1]

* Listen to task updates:

    `rostopic echo /srcsim/finals/task`

        ---
        task: 1
        current_checkpoint: 1
        checkpoints_completion: []
        start_time: 
          secs: 65
          nsecs:  21000000
        elapsed_time: 
          secs: 3
          nsecs: 609000000
        timed_out: False
        finished: False
        ---

* Walk to satellite (drag robot using the translate tool)

* See that checkpoint 1 is finished. Status messages should look like this:

        ---
        task: 1
        current_checkpoint: 2
        checkpoints_completion: 
          - 
            secs: 95
            nsecs: 21000000
        start_time: 
          secs: 65
          nsecs:  21000000
        elapsed_time: 
          secs: 30
          nsecs: 000000000
        timed_out: False
        finished: False
        ---

* And the console should say:

        [Msg] Stopped box contains plugin [task1/checkpoint1]
        [Msg] Task [1] - Checkpoint [1] - Completed (59 257000000)
        [Msg] Task [1] - Checkpoint [2] - Started (59 257000000)

* Skip to Checkpoint 3:

    `rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 1 3`

* The console should say:

        [Msg] Task [1] - Checkpoint [2] - Skipped (28 985000000)
        [Msg] Task [1] - Checkpoint [3] - Started (28 985000000)
        [Msg] Started box contains plugin [task1/checkpoint3]

* See that checkpoint 2 is marked as skipped (time == 0)

        ---
        task: 1
        current_checkpoint: 3
        checkpoints_completion: 
          - 
            secs: 95
            nsecs: 21000000
          - 
            secs: 0
            nsecs:         0
        start_time: 
          secs: 65
          nsecs:  21000000
        elapsed_time: 
          secs: 50
          nsecs: 000000000
        timed_out: False
        finished: False
        ---

* Wait for Task 1 to timeout (timeout is 3 mins for debugging)

* See that we moved to task 2

        ---
        task: 1
        current_checkpoint: 0
        checkpoints_completion: 
          - 
            secs: 95
            nsecs: 21000000
          - 
            secs: 0
            nsecs:         0
          - 
            secs: 0
            nsecs:         0
        start_time: 
          secs: 65
          nsecs:  21000000
        elapsed_time: 
          secs: 50
          nsecs: 000000000
        timed_out: True
        finished: False
        ---
        task: 2
        current_checkpoint: 1
        checkpoints_completion: []
        start_time: 
          secs: 200
          nsecs:  21000000
        elapsed_time: 
          secs: 10
          nsecs: 000000000
        timed_out: False
        finished: False
        ---

### API

#### Start task / checkpoint

`rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 1 1`

* The service arguments correspond to the task id and the checkpoint id respectively.

* Once a checkpoint has been completed, the next checkpoint is available.

* Similarly, once a task has been completed, the next task is available. Beware that each task has a timeout.

* It's not possible to restart the current checkpoint or to go back to an earlier checkpoint.

#### Listen to task status

`rostopic echo /srcsim/finals/task`

* This has the status of the current task and all its checkpoints, as shown on the example above.

### What can be tested

* Try skipping to various tasks and checkpoints

* Verify it's not possible to go back to a previous checkpoint

* Look for any inconsistencies on the task status

* Check that timeouts work

* Check that robot is teleported when checkpoints are skipped

* **NEW**: Try the box checkpoints (T1CP1 (walk to satellite), T1CP3 (finish box 1), T2CP6 (finish box 2))

* **NEW**: Try the satellite checkpoint

values.description:
This adds a check for two environment variables:

* `USE_CUSTOM_WORLD`: 1 to use a custom world, 0 to use the world installed with the package
* `CUSTOM_WORLD_PATH`: Full path to a custom world, including filename, for example `~/worlds/new.world`

## Usage

By default, the variables are not set and users will use the installed world.

In case users want to use a custom world:

1. Generate custom world using erb and save it to a specific path, for example:

        erb unique.world.erb > ~/worlds/new.world

1. Set environment variables:

        export USE_CUSTOM_WORLD=1
        export CUSTOM_WORLD_PATH=~/worlds/new.world

1. roslaunch as usual

## The need for 2 variables

@dirk-thomas, I ended up using two separate variables for this because it looks like roslaunch's `if` requires a bool. So when I did 

`if="$(optenv CUSTOM_WORLD_PATH 0)"`

And the variable was set, I'd get an error:

`~/worlds/new.world is not a 'bool' type`

Please let me know if you can think of a solution using only one env variable. Otherwise I think this is not a very big compromise.

## Tutorial

Added instructions to the tutorial:

#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/finals
values.title: Allow using custom world paths by checking environment variables

values.description:
Add the solar panel model and a plugin which deploys the panel when its button is pressed.

![sp3.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2798895465-sp3.png)

![sp1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3683688321-sp1.png)

* The total mass of the panel has been set to 5 kg. It would be nice to randomize this within a range. Maybe from 4 to 6 kg?

* 80% of the mass is on the base, so the panel tends to fall in the vertical and is more stable after deployed.

![sp4.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2752603032-sp4.png)

![sp2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1787119936-sp2.png)

* I left the collisions as trimeshes, but we might need to revisit this and use simple shapes instead. It will be hard to match all the little details which are good for grasping though.

* The button needs to be in contact with something while it's pressed to be triggered.

* The plugin can be toggled on and off through gazebo topic `/task2/checkpoint3/toggle`. This is used by `Task2CP3`

* The solar panel is integrated into the world generator, but its pose will change, since we need to place it inside the rover.



### How to try it

1. `unique.world` now includes the solar panel, so you can launch it:

    `roslaunch srcsim unique.launch init:=true`

1. Wait for `INIT: Done`

1. Skip to the solar panel checkpoint. Since there are no other checkpoints before it on Task2 yet, you can do:

    `rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 1`

1. You'll see a message:

        [Msg] Task [1] - Skipped (26 584000000)
        [Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [1] - Started (26 584000000)
        success: True 
        [Msg] Started solar panel plugin

1. You can try moving the panel around and it shouldn't open.

1. Throw something onto the button and it will open.

1. You'll see a message like:

        [Msg] Solar panel is open
        [Msg] Stopped solar panel plugin
        [Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [1] - Completed (38 795000000)
        [Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [2] - Started (38 795000000)
        [Msg] Started box contains plugin [task2/checkpoint6]

### Example

Here's an example video:

https://youtu.be/FLFzsrpJm_k

values.description:
This is the rover where the solar panel from pull request #34 will be placed:

![rover2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2661561040-rover2.png)

* It's a static model which won't be moved

* The collision shapes which will be in contact with the solar panel and potentially the robot were carefully placed to match the visuals. The rest of the rover has a generic box collision. Let me know if you see any problem with this and I can work on more detailed collisions for the rest of the rover:

![rover3.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1374181416-rover3.png)

This is the rover where the solar panel from pull request #34 will be placed:

![rover2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2661561040-rover2.png)

* It's a static model which won't be moved

* The collision shapes which will be in contact with the solar panel and potentially the robot were carefully placed to match the visuals. The rest of the rover has a generic box collision. Let me know if you see any problem with this and I can work on more detailed collisions for the rest of the rover:

values.description:
This is the table for task 3. It will be inside the habitat and have a couple tools on top of it. It's not expected that the robot will interact much with this model.

* It's a static model, so its dynamics are not important
* Simple shapes are used as collision to simplify contact between the tools and the table, and in case the robot touches the table.

![spacetable.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1026612086-spacetable.png)

values.description:
Air leak detector model for the finals task 3.

* For now, the mass is 1 kg, this it how the mass and inertia look like:

‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/8195950-detector1.png)

* I left the collisions as trimeshes since this object will be grasped. We can revisit this later and use simple shapes as needed. Used the same contact parameters as the table, but the contacts don't look very stable. There's an ongoing discussion about this on pull request #34.


* Integrated it into the world together with the table at a placeholder location, but these models will be moved once the habitat is integrated.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3459735750-detec3.png)

‌

### UPDATE 288ef0f

* Scaled down so it fits nicely inside Val's hand. I was able to grasp it using @scpeters 's grasping controllers:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/4177245189-det4.png)

values.description:
Add solar array model for task 2. This is what it looks like near the robot:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3098481060-solararray.png)

* It's a static model
* Used same contact params as other models
* The cable is being modeled as a separate model, so it's not included in this pull request.
* There is one large box collision for the area which will touch other models:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/687235494-array3.png)

* For the rest of the model, I used the trimesh for collision. With the detail that I made it slightly smaller than the visual. So in the box area, we know objects will be touching the box, not the trimesh. And in the rest of the model, there's a slight offset between visual and collision. Here's the difference between the visuals on the box corner, when hiding the extra box collision:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/643693846-array4.png)

values.description:
Add the cable model for task 2.

* The cable is placed in such a way that it starts laying on top of the solar array from pull request #41. It starts in a zig-zag configuration

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3509746750-cable1_small.png)

* The cable is composed of 16 cylindrical links connected by universal joints, plus a spherical link attached to the array.
* All collisions are simple shapes
* The mass of each link is 50 g, so the whole cable weighs `50 * 17 == 0.85 kg`

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3635023652-cable4.png)

* If the inertias for each link were calculated based on a cylinder, they end up being too small and the physics gets a bit crazy. So I capped the minimum value for the inertial components to be 0.0001, which results on inertias larger than the shape of the cable.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2082347044-cable5.png)

* The cable is long enough to reach the other end of the array

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/92030115-cable2.png)

* Surface properties have been chosen so they match other models

summary.html:
Add the cable model for task 2.

  • The cable is placed in such a way that it starts laying on top of the solar array from pull request #41. It starts in a zig-zag configuration

  • The cable is composed of 16 cylindrical links connected by universal joints, plus a spherical link attached to the array.
  • All collisions are simple shapes
  • The mass of each link is 50 g, so the whole cable weighs 50 * 17 == 0.85 kg

  • If the inertias for each link were calculated based on a cylinder, they end up being too small and the physics gets a bit crazy. So I capped the minimum value for the inertial components to be 0.0001, which results on inertias larger than the shape of the cable.

  • The cable is long enough to reach the other end of the array

  • Surface properties have been chosen so they match other models

values.description:
Add the checkpoint to lift the solar panel.

* Makes use of Gazebo7's new `TouchPlugin`, which should be released on Gazebo 7.6.0 later today.
* Right now, it checks whether the robot is the only thing touching the panel for 5 seconds continuously. We can change this time later if needed.
* `TouchCheckpoint` will be used for several other checkpoints.

‌

### How to test it

Forgive the messy formatting, it looks like Bitbucket has put me in some trial for their new editor and it's buggy :/

1. Make sure you're running Gazebo 7.6 before building
2. After building, launch `unique.launch` as usual:

         roslaunch srcsim unique.launch init:=true
    1. After `Init: Done`, skip to Task 2, Checkpoint 1. This will place the robot in the middle of final box 1.

            rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 1
        1. You'll see a message:

    `[Msg] Task [1] - Skipped (26 86000000)`

    `[Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [1] - Started (26 86000000) success: True`

    `[Msg] Started touch plugin [task2/checkpoint1]`
3.   
4.  4. Pause the simulation and use the translate and rotate tools to place the panel above Val's arms (careful for it not to overlap with Val, we don't want any explosions) 5. Press play again and the panel will fall and rest on Val's arms. The contacts look stable enough for the plugin to work (we're getting at least 5s of continuous contact):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1149291489-t2cp1.png)

1. The moment the panel touches Val, you'll see this message:

         [Msg] Model [solar_panel] started touching [valkyrie] at 38 723000000 seconds
    1. After 0.5 seconds, you'll see:

    \[Msg\] Model \[solar\_panel\] touched \[valkyrie\] exclusively for 0 500000000 seconds

    \[Msg\] Stopped touch plugin \[task2/checkpoint1\]

    \[Msg\] Task \[2\] - Checkpoint \[1\] - Completed (39 223000000)

‌
values.title: Task 2 Checkpoint 1 (TouchCheckpoint)

values.description:
Add the checkpoint to place the solar panel on the array. 

* Use a `BoxCheckpoint` to check when the solar panel enters a box on top of the array, the blue box represents the volume which is being checked (I put it there for the screenshot)

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2305091651-t2cp2.png)

* It was decided that it won't be possible to skip directly to checkpoints after another checkpoint which involves lifting an object. So we're not allowing direct skips to 2/2. I plan on refactoring the code involved if there's time eventually.

‌

# How to test it

## Not possible to skip

You can test that it isn't possible to skip by running:

`rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 2`

You'll see the message:

`[Err] [FinalsPlugin.cc:206] It's not possible to skip to task [2] checkpoint [2] (2/2). You can either complete 2/1 and then skip to 2/3, or skip straight to to 2/3.`

And nothing should happen.

## Test the plugin

While pull request #44 is not merged, we can actually test this checkpoint in a **hacky** way as follows:

Skip to 2/1. Since the other PR is not merged, we end up on this one.

`rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 1`

Val will explode and fly away, it doesn't matter because we just want to test the plugin.

You'll see this message:

`[Msg] Started box contains plugin [task2/checkpoint2]`

Now pause simulation and use the translate tool to place the solar panel on top of the solar array.

You'll immediately see this message:

    [Msg] Stopped box contains plugin [task2/checkpoint2]
    [Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [1] - Completed (29 335000000)
values.title: Task 2 Checkpoint 2

values.description:
For task 1, teleporting the robot when a checkpoint is skipped was enough.

For tasks 2 and 3, skipping some checkpoints also involves doing things to other models. I started a [wiki page](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/skip_summary) with a summary of skipping behaviors.

This pull request puts in place some of the logic needed for that and implements skipping task 2 checkpoint 3, which means the solar panel is opened.

### How to test it

a. Start a run and wait for `Init: Done` 

    roslaunch srcsim unique.launch init:="true"

b. Skip to checkpoint 2/1:

    rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 1

Val will be teleported to the center of the first finish box.

c. Try to skip to checkpoint 2/2:

    rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 2

That should fail with a message:

    [Err] [FinalsPlugin.cc:207] It's not possible to skip to task [2] checkpoint [2] (2/2). You can either complete 2/1 and then skip to 2/3, or skip straight to 2/3.
    success: False

d. Skip to checkpoint 2/3:

    rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 3

Val will be teleported to the solar array.

**The solar panel is not teleported yet, this is coming in a future pull request**

d. Skip to checkpoint 2/4:

    rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 4

The panel will open (in place), Val stays in place

‌
values.title: Skip affecting other models

For tasks 2 and 3, skipping some checkpoints also involves doing things to other models. I started a wiki page with a summary of skipping behaviors.

This pull request puts in place some of the logic needed for that and implements skipping task 2 checkpoint 3, which means the solar panel is opened.

How to test it

a. Start a run and wait for Init: Done 

roslaunch srcsim unique.launch init:="true"

b. Skip to checkpoint 2/1:

rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 1

Val will be teleported to the center of the first finish box.

c. Try to skip to checkpoint 2/2:

rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 2

That should fail with a message:

[Err] [FinalsPlugin.cc:207] It's not possible to skip to task [2] checkpoint [2] (2/2). You can either complete 2/1 and then skip to 2/3, or skip straight to 2/3.
success: False

d. Skip to checkpoint 2/3:

rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 3

Val will be teleported to the solar array.

The solar panel is not teleported yet, this is coming in a future pull request

d. Skip to checkpoint 2/4:

rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 4

The panel will open (in place), Val stays in place

‌

values.description:
This builds on top of pull request #44

Use the touch plugin to check when the robot has been the only thing touching the cable's tip (its last link) continuously for 0.5 seconds.

## How to test

1. Skip to 2/4:

        rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 4

1. The robot will be teleported to face the array and you'll see this message:

        [Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [4] - Started (30 293000000)
        success: True
        [Msg] Started touch plugin [task2/checkpoint4]

1. Now… figure out a way to pick up the cable and verify it works :) I test this with a combination of @scpeters 's [grasping controller](https://github.com/scpeters/val_grasping) and using the [Force/Torque dialog](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=apply_force_torque) to push the cable towards Val's hand.

    (i.e. Pause the world, apply between 100 ~ 400 N in the desired direction, step the world a few times to see how the cable is moving, then apply force again… Until the cable is inside the hand. Make the hand close, then step more and adjust the cable as needed. Not elegant, I know…)

1. While the grasping is halfway there and choppy, your terminal will be spammed like:

        [Msg] Model [solar_panel_cable] started touching [valkyrie] at 45 268000000 seconds
        [Msg] Not touching anything
        [Msg] Model [solar_panel_cable] started touching [valkyrie] at 45 303000000 seconds
        [Msg] Not touching anything
        [Msg] Model [solar_panel_cable] started touching [valkyrie] at 45 325000000 seconds
        [Msg] Not touching anything
        [Msg] Model [solar_panel_cable] started touching [valkyrie] at 45 346000000 seconds
        [Msg] Not touching anything
        [Msg] Model [solar_panel_cable] started touching [valkyrie] at 45 357000000 seconds
        …

1. Then finally you get a good grip:

    ![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2661890985-t2cp4.png)

1. Wait ~~5~~ 0.5 seconds, and the checkpoint is complete:

        [Msg] Model [solar_panel_cable] started touching [valkyrie] at 45 675000000 seconds
        [Msg] Model [solar_panel_cable] touched [valkyrie] exclusively for 0 500000000 seconds
        [Msg] Stopped touch plugin [task2/checkpoint4]
        [Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [4] - Completed (50 677000000)
        [Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [5] - Started (50 677000000)

‌

‌

values.description:
Add the checkpoint to plug the cable onto the solar panel.

* I tried a different approach here and instead of writing a model plugin, I wrote the logic directly into the Task implementation
* This is similar to `TouchPlugin` , but after contact has been held for a while, a fixed joint between the plug and the outlet is created.
* Added a dedicated cylindrical collision for the outlet onto the solar panel.
    ![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/933378933-t2cp5_2.png)
* Contact is stable between the plug and the outlet and I was able to plug it in teleoperating Val:
    ![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1120564973-t2cp5.png)
* Because of the contact parameters, the cable enters the outlet, which in the end I think is a cool effect:
    ![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3688958305-t2cp5_3.png)

## How to test it

1. Skip to this checkpoint
2. Find a way to drop the cable plug right on top of the outlet
3. The moment they touch, you'll see:
    `[Msg] Plug started touching outlet at 251 520000000 seconds` 
4. After they are touching continuously for 5 seconds, you'll see:

        [Msg] The cable plug has been fixed to the outlet
        [Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [5] - Completed (256 521000000)
        [Msg] Task [2] - Checkpoint [6] - Started (256 521000000)
        [Msg] Started box contains plugin [task2/checkpoint6]

How to test it

  3. The moment they touch, you'll see: [Msg] Plug started touching outlet at 251 520000000 seconds

values.description:
This pull request contains all the changes needed to release Task 2. This includes changes from other open pull requests plus some changes on top.

I decided to make this pull request so others have a chance to try everything together while reviewing the other pull requests, if they want to.

As other pull requests are merged, this one will get smaller. Feel free to review this pull request directly if you're more comfortable with that.

Pull requests contained in this one:

* ~~pull request #38~~
* ~~pull request #44~~
* ~~pull request #45~~
* ~~pull request #46~~
* ~~pull request #47~~
* ~~pull request #48~~

I've added instructions to the [wiki](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/finals_task2).

### Summary

* Added start boxes (see tutorial)
* Passing SDF pointers directly to tasks and checkpoints
* Changed the skip pose logic:
    * Before (`<task_N_checkpoint_M_pose>`): Pose before the checkpoint
    * After (`<taskN><checkpointM><robot_skip_pose>`): Pose after the checkpoint
* Added `unique_task2.world` and `unique_task2.launch`
* Panel is also teleported when skipping T2CP2
